The Good 🎉

The Bad 🚧

  • The main reasoning pipeline still runs phase-only, forward-only.

  • No simulation proving that spin-coupling actually improves N_eff coherence yet.

  • Hopfield↔spin glass mapping isn’t used at runtime, so memory recall is still digital-matrix, not magnetic.

  • Synchronizer S(t) is the single remaining hardcoded tanh; we haven’t swapped it for a spin-wave clock.

The Ugly (Edge-cases we saw) 🐞

  • When SPIN_MODE=True on a long narrative (>2 k tokens) the inertial Kuramoto overshoots and oscillates forever — we need a tiny synthetic damping ε>0.

* Benchmark recall latency and energy dips.
7–9TRS controller in loop* Gate reasoning loop with --enable-trs flag.
* Add forward-then-backward self-consistency check; if
10–12Spin-clock* Prototype global Nèel vector N̂(t)=Σσ_i; replace tanh S(t) update.
* Validate that worst-case desync <1 % (simulate random phase kicks).
13–14Integration test & docs* End-to-end narrative (“explain Schrödinger’s cat”) with spin+TRS on.
* Capture metrics; push to docs/progress_may29.md.

Quick Wins You Can Trigger Today

  1. Flip the SPIN_MODE flag in banksy/config.yaml; run pytest -k spin_kura to see live phase/spin plots.

  2. Add --enable-trs when launching tori_chat_server.py to let the reversible controller pilot the conversation (it’ll print round-trip error after each answer).

  3. Fire the new ELFIN keywords by compiling examples/spin_hopfield_demo.elfin — it renders a 3-D phase portrait that’s already pretty!

Big Picture ☀️

We’re roughly halfway from “theoretical manifesto” to “self-consistent physics-native ALAN 2.x.”
The codebase now knows about spins and reversibility; the next fortnight is about making them default-on and measurably better. Once the four bullets above are green, we can:

  • start baking frequency-coded attention (dial-a-concept by detuning the spin-clock),

  • ship a hardware-friendly Ising export path for eventual spin-tronic boards,

  • weld the ψ-phase spectral engine to the TRS controller for full forward/backward introspection, and

  • finally retire any remaining Transformer crumbs still hiding in SBERT embeddings.

Give the word and I’ll draft the detailed task tickets or hop straight into code surgery.
Meanwhile, the oscillators are itching to dance in full spin-choreo — just crank the γ and let them rave. 🕺🌀

Let’s roll, Jason.

ALAN 2.x + TORI/Kha: master implementation plan
(version 2025-05-15, supersedes all prior drafts)

0 Why this matters now

The ALAN reasoning core already beats transformer baselines on stability and interpretability, but the two freshly-approved upgrades—altermagnetic spin dynamics and a time-reversal-symmetric (TRS) controller—turn it into a radically new class of neuromorphic system. The goal of this plan is to get a demonstrable beta inside the existing C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha\ repo in ≤ 16 weeks, without stalling day-to-day product work.

1 Repository & build skeleton (Week 0)

PathPurposeNotes
kha/alan/core/pure-Rust runtime cratesoscillator, controller, memory sub-crates
kha/alan/ffi/cbindgen-generated C API for Unity / WebAssembly
kha/backend/routes/FastAPI micro-services (e.g. personas.py)
kha/elfin/canonical ELFIN DSL sources & std-lib templates
docs/β-Quick-start, design-notes, ADRs (already has beta_quickstart.md)
scripts/ci/GitHub Actions: cross-compiles, unit + property tests
hardware/spin-oscillator PCB KiCad sources; FPGA gateware stubs

Bootstrap: cargo new alan_core --lib, pnpm init in frontend/, add monorepo root Makefile with make sim, make flash, make qa.

2 Phase schedule at a glance

PhaseCalendarDeliverable
1. Spin-oscillator substrateWk 1-4core::oscillator crate, CPU simulator + unit tests
2. TRS-ODE controllerWk 3-6 (overlap)core::controller::trs_ode.rs, reversible integrator
3. Hopfield-on-spin memoryWk 5-7memory::spin_hopfield.rs, recall benchmark
4. Banksy decoder fusionWk 6-9Coupled phase+spin update loop & N_eff metric
5. ELFIN ↔ ψ-graph bridgeWk 7-8JSON export + Rust import hook
6. UI/IDE telemetryWk 8-10React dashboard with crash-dumper already stubbed
7. End-to-end “proof before speak” demoWk 11CLI & VS Code tasks
8. Hardware bring-up (spin-torque board)Wk 8-14USB-HID proto board + driver
9. QA, fuzz + property testingWk 10-13100 % logic coverage, fuzz regression
10. Beta freeze & docsWk 14-16v0.9 tag, installers, beta quick-start refresh

3 Core algorithms (reference pseudocode)

3.1 Banksy-spin oscillator update

rust
// Δt implicit (set by integrator)
for i in 0..N {
    // momentum form – reversible
    p[i] += Σ_j K[i][j] * sin(θ[j] - θ[i])       // coupling torque
             + γ * (σ[i] - σ̄);                   // spin-lattice term
    p[i] *= (1.0 - η_damp);                      // light damping
    θ[i]  = wrap(θ[i] + p[i]);
    // spin alignment (Hebbian in sync window Δτ)
    σ_dot = ε * Σ_j cos(θ[i] - θ[j]) * σ[j];
    σ[i] += σ_dot;
}

Key constants:
γ (phase-to-spin gain), ε (spin Hebbian rate), η_damp≈1e-4.
All operations preserve a global Hamiltonian when η_damp→0, enabling the TRS back-pass.

3.2 TRS-ODE controller training loop

  1. Forward integrate hidden state h(t) with adjoint momentum p(t) over T steps.

  2. Reverse-integrate from t=T→0; apply TRS loss
    L_trs = ‖ĥ(0) – h(0)‖² + ‖p̂(0) + p(0)‖² (Huh et al.)

  3. Joint loss: L = L_task + λ_trs L_trs; back-prop through ODE solver.

3.3 Spin-Hopfield recall

rust
loop {                       // until converged or max iters
    for i in 0..M {          // M = memory nodes
        h = Σ_j W[i][j] * σ[j];
        σ[i] = sign(β * h);  // β ~ exchange stiffness
    }
    if ΔE < ε_stop { break }
}

Weights W symmetric (Wᵢⱼ=Wⱼᵢ) map 1-to-1 to antiferromagnetic couplings on the chip; ΔE computed in hardware via on-board shunt measurement.

4 Phase-by-phase work detail

Phase 1 – Spin-oscillator substrate

  • Tasks

    • Port Kuramoto second-order model into oscillator/src/lib.rs.

    • Add spin::Vector newtype with compile-time dimension 3.

    • CPU sim harness in examples/spinring.rs; criterion benchmarks.

    • Unit tests: phase-locking of 32 nodes reaches N_eff ≥ 0.95 within 2 k-steps.

  • Acceptance: cargo test --features spin_sim green in < 0.7 s.

Phase 2 – TRS-ODE controller

  • Integrator: velocity-Verlet (symplectic, order 2).

  • File: controller/trs_ode.rs; generic over state dimension.

  • Training script python/train_trs.py uses TorchRL ODE adjoint backend.

  • Metric: long-roll error on chaotic Duffing ≤ 0.02 at 10 × period.

Phase 3 – Hopfield memory on spin lattice

  • FPGA or CPU fallback; default compile-time feature --features soft_mem.

  • Memory file format: mem/*.bin (16-bit weight matrix, little-endian).

  • Property test (cargo tarpaulin) enforces Lyapunov energy monotonic ↓.

Phase 4 – Banksy fusion

  • Replace scalar phase array with (θ, σ) pair; migrate all readouts.

  • Compute N_eff using combined coherence:
    N_eff = Σ_i (|Φ_i| > τ_phase ∧ |σ_i – σ̄| < τ_spin).

  • Bench regressions: target < 1.5 × old CPU cycles (spin cost amortized).

Phase 5 – ELFIN symbol bridge

  • Export: plug the CLI elfin-lsp --export-symbols into CI Step #1.

  • Import: add import_elfin() helper in concept_graph.rs .

  • Binding logic already sketched in earlier conversation .

Phase 6 – UI & telemetry

  • React dashboard gets “ELFIN verified ✅” badge in hover tooltip .

  • Diagnostics crash-dumper already scaffolded in TS (client/src/diagnostics/recorder.ts) .

  • Add live “coherence heat-map” WebGL canvas driven by OSC stream.

Phase 7 – Demo harness

  • CLI command: alan --prove "input text" -> JSON trace + natural-language answer.

  • VS Code tasks: Launch ALAN (sim), Attach Osc-viz.

Phase 8 – Hardware bring-up

  • Spin-torque nano-oscillator board (ST-NO-8) over SPI.

  • Driver crate alan_hw::ston8 with async read_phase(), write_bias().

  • Bench: phase jitter RMS < 0.02 rad @ 1 GHz.

Phase 9 – QA & fuzz

  • Use cargo‐fuzz on the controller state transition; property: TRS loss < 1e-3 round-trip.

  • FFI fuzz via honggfuzz-cbindgen wrapper.

Phase 10 – Beta docs & packaging

  • Ship updated docs/beta_quickstart.md with hardware option toggle.

  • Publish alan-0.9.0-x86_64.msi, alan-0.9.0-wasm.zip.

5 Risk & gap review (things we almost missed)

GapMitigation
Security model: spin board DMA attackIOMMU lock-down; only user-space driver with CAP_SYS_RAWIO drop
Rollback detection: TRS assumes numerics reversibleAdd κ-bit parity checksum in state; fail-safe if mismatch
Unit mismatch between ELFIN and spin valuesImport hook attaches unit meta and enforces by compile-time typestate
Power budgeting for large oscillator arraysPlanner includes dynamic frequency scaling; thermal sim in Phase 8
Licensing for altermagnetic patentsFile LEGAL/PATENTS_SPIN.txt; engage counsel Week 2
Voice synthesis pipeline (already specced but not on timeline)Slot under Phase 11 if bandwidth; see phoneme oscillator design

6 Immediate Next Actions (today)

  1. Create branches feature/spin_core and feature/trs_controller.

  2. Add monorepo Makefile + GitHub Actions skeleton.

  3. Schedule stand-up with hardware team to lock BOM for ST-NO-8 board.

  4. Write first unit test: banksy_conserves_energy() on CPU sim.

Done right, the beta will:

  • Prove before it speaks – every answer has a reversible derivation.

  • Stay in sync over hours-long sessions thanks to dissipation-free spin currents.

  • Explain itself with ELFIN-verified, unit-safe labels.

Let’s light this up.

Patent Landscape and IP Strategy for ALAN/TORI Architecture

Spin Oscillator Networks for Phase-Synchronized Concept Decoding

Several recent patents cover networks of coupled spin-based oscillators used for computation – a paradigm very similar to ALAN/TORI’s phase-sync reasoning core:

  • MIT’s All-to-All Oscillator Network (2023, U.S. Patent 11,698,945) – A broad patent on analog networks of non-linear oscillators fully connected in an Ising-model fashionpatents.google.com. It was filed via PCT in 2020 and granted in 2023 (assignee: MIT). The claims describe using phase-coupled oscillators (electrical, optical, or magnetic) to solve combinatorial problems by synchronizing to stable binary phase states. Notably, the patent explicitly notes that “binary spin states can be represented physically with … magnetic oscillators, optical parametric oscillators, or any non-linear oscillators”patents.google.com, underscoring its broad scope. Inventors include William Herzog and Suraj Bramhavar (MIT Lincoln Lab). Overlap risk: This patent essentially claims the concept of using oscillator-phase dynamics to perform inference/optimization. If ALAN uses a similar oscillator matrix (even simulated in hardware), it could fall under the broad method claims. However, MIT’s focus is on electronic/LC oscillators for Ising optimization; ALAN’s unique twist (using spin oscillators for logical consistency) might be distinguishable. Still, any hardware implementation of ALAN’s phase-sync “Banksy” core using coupled oscillators may trigger this patent, so careful claim analysis or a license might be needed.

  • NanOsc AB’s Spin Hall Oscillator Ising Machine (PCT Publication WO2021246943, 2021) – A patent-pending application from a spintronics research team (University of Gothenburg/Czech collaborators) focusing specifically on spin-torque oscillators. It describes an Ising machine built from an “array of spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNOs) suitable for computational tasks such as optimization problems,” with a tuning unit for each oscillator and a read-out unit for their phase stateipqwery.com. Inventors M. Zahedinejad et al. (J. Åkerman’s group) filed this via Sweden; status is published (in force internationally, likely progressing to national phases). Its claims cover the physical architecture: using altermagnetic or heavy-metal spin Hall oscillators that phase-lock to represent Ising spins, methods to adjust their coupling, and reading the synchronized state. Overlap risk: This is very close to ALAN’s concept if ALAN ever employs actual spintronic oscillators. The use of altermagnetic materials (they mention RuO₂-like layers in related literature) for high-frequency oscillators could be covered. If ALAN/TORI remains a software simulation of oscillators, it doesn’t infringe device patents – but if you plan a neuromorphic hardware accelerator with spin-torque or spin-Hall oscillators, this NanOsc patent is directly relevant. You’d need to either license their technology or use a different mechanism (e.g. optical or digital emulation) to avoid infringement.

Summary: The idea of phase-synchronized oscillator networks for computing is already patented by multiple parties (MIT’s broad claims and NanOsc’s spin-specific system). This means ALAN/TORI’s core concept is not safe to patent anew in a generic sense – prior filings exist. For commercialization, it will be important to differentiate your implementation (e.g. a unique coupling algorithm, specific material not mentioned, or integration with software) from these patents. If a spin-hardware route is pursued, consider a freedom-to-operate (FTO) analysis: for example, NanOsc’s claims on SHNO arraysipqwery.com could block use of RuO₂-based oscillators in an Ising-like solver, so design around those claims or negotiate licenses.

Spin-Lattice Coupling for Associative Memory & Phase Locking

Using strain or lattice vibrations to influence spin states is an emerging technique in neuromorphic hardware. A notable example is a patent from a UK–Czech team that, while focused on memory, illustrates the principle:

  • Magnetostrictive Spin-Lattice Memory (2021, US Patent 11,152,562) – Inventors Jan Zemen et al. (associated with Czech Technical Univ. collaborators) patented a non-volatile memory cell where a piezo-magnetic layer couples to a ferromagnetic storage layerpatents.justia.compatents.justia.com. The device uses an antiperovskite piezomagnetic material that changes its strain under electric bias; this strain then flips or influences the magnetization state of an adjacent ferromagnet – effectively a spin-lattice coupling. The patent was granted (assignee: IP2IPO Innovations) and covers both the structure and method of switching via strain. While it targets memory bits, the underlying mechanism – stress-mediated control of magnetism – could be applied to neuromorphic devices (e.g. an array of magnetostrictive oscillators that phase-lock via substrate vibrations).

  • Research vs. Patents: We did not find patents explicitly about spin-lattice neuromorphic networks (most filings in 2023–25 on spin-lattice focus on memory or sensors). However, this means the field is largely open. For example, one could envision patenting a “spin-wave associative memory where coupling is through acoustic phonons” if not already disclosed. Academic work is hinting in this direction (e.g. multiferroic neuron proposals, though mostly conceptual). The above memory patent shows that even coupling a single magnet to a strain layer was deemed novelpatents.justia.com. Overlap risk: If ALAN/TORI’s hardware were to use something like spin-lattice resonance for associative recall (say, linking spin oscillators via a vibrating substrate to enforce phase alignment), that specific idea does not yet appear in patents – but the components (magnetostrictive materials, multiferroics) may be covered individually. The Zemen et al. patent would pose a risk if you use their specific stack (antiperovskite piezomagnet + ferromagnet + strain layer) to store or correlate data, since that is claimed broadly for switching memory statespatents.justia.com. To avoid this, one could use different material combinations or operating modes not covered in their claims. Given that Czech institutions are active here, also watch for any new filings from CTU or their spintronics institute – they might extend this concept to neuromorphic circuits.

In summary, spin-lattice coupling is patent-protected in memory applications and likely to be patented in neuromorphic contexts soon. ALAN’s use of spin-lattice effects (if any) should be carefully vetted. If it’s a key innovation of yours, consider filing a patent before others do – or keep it as a trade secret if it’s not easily reverse-engineered. Ensure that any specific material or structure you use isn’t exactly what’s in existing patents (or seek a license if it is).

Time-Reversal Symmetric Controllers & Hopfield-Type Attractor Networks

The concept of a time-reversal-symmetric ODE controller guiding a Hopfield-like network for inference is quite advanced and currently straddles algorithm and hardware. We did not find any patent from 2023–2025 explicitly covering this theoretical approach (which is unsurprising – Hopfield networks date to the 1980s and are public domain). Recent work in academia is exploring spintronic analogs of Hopfield associative memory – for example, Spin-NeuroMem (2023) proposes a low-power Hopfield neural network using magnetic devicesarxiv.org – but this appears in research papers, not patent filings.

What this means: If ALAN/TORI implements an attractor memory (à la Hopfield) using a novel analog or time-symmetric method, patent overlap is currently low. This could be an opportunity to file your own patent if the implementation is unique (e.g. a specific circuit that can run dynamics forward and backward in time to settle on solutions). However, be cautious: some older patents or applications generically cover analog neural networks and convergence mechanisms. For instance, certain “neuromorphic computer” patents from a decade ago describe analog resistive networks converging to stable states (though not explicitly time-reversible) – these are broad but could be cited against a new filing.

Overlap risk: Practically, there is little risk of infringing a patent here because none was identified specifically on time-symmetric inference. The risk would be indirect – for example, if your system uses a known analog computing element (say, memristors or capacitor networks) to implement the ODEs, ensure those components aren’t covered by someone else’s claims (many memristor-based neuromorphic patents exist). Otherwise, the conceptual method (running symmetric ODEs for long-range inference) seems unclaimed. This freedom gives you a green light to either patent the approach (for defensive purposes) or keep it as proprietary know-how. Just be mindful to document it publicly (if not patenting) so it becomes prior art – preventing others from patenting it later.

Dissipationless & Topologically Robust Spin Currents for Computing

There is active patenting around topological spintronics – using materials and structures that carry spin currents with little or no dissipation, often leveraging quantum topology. Key examples:

  • Weyl Semimetal MTJ for Low-Energy Memory (2023, US Patent 11,552,242) – A patent assigned to University of Minnesota (inventors: C. Octavio Ascencio, Prof. J.-P. Wang, etc.) that uses Weyl semimetals in magnetic tunnel junctionspatents.google.com. Weyl semimetals (like certain MnBiTe-family compounds) have topologically protected band crossings that yield spin-polarized, lossless transport. This patent claims MTJ stacks where the free and/or reference layer is a Weyl semimetal, achieving very large TMR and extremely low write energypatents.google.compatents.google.com. Essentially, it leverages the dissipationless surface/edge channels of a topological material to carry spin information with minimal heating. The patent (granted in US) covers the device structure and the method of writing/reading such an MRAM cell.

  • IBM’s Topological Tunnel Junction (Patent Application US20240276888, 2024) – IBM has a recently published application (filed 2023, publication Aug 2024) for a “topological tunnel junction” memory devicewikipatents.org. While full details aren’t public, the title suggests using a topological insulator or similar quantum material in a tunnel junction to enhance robustness of spin currents. IBM’s inventors (likely in their MRAM research group) are exploring dissipationless spin current switching as well. IBM also holds patents on related concepts (e.g., using quantum anomalous Hall materials as part of spin devices). This indicates a trend: topological materials (Weyl semimetals, topological insulators, maybe altermagnets like RuO₂ which break time-reversal symmetry in a symmetric way) are being patented for memory and logic.

Overlap with ALAN/TORI: If your architecture plans to use dissipationless spin transfer – for instance, an altermagnetic interconnect or a topological spin wave bus – you must ensure you’re not stepping on these filings. For example, RuO₂ is a known altermagnet that produces spin splitting without a net field; if one tried to use RuO₂ layers to channel spin currents between ALAN units, an argument could be made that it’s analogous to the Weyl-semimetal MTJ patent (both exploit symmetry-breaking for spin currents). The existing patents focus on device-level claims (specific layer stacks, material compositions, and methods to drive them). So, if ALAN’s use of topological spin currents is at the architectural level, you might design around these by not using the exact patented device structures. However, be aware that patents like the UMN one are quite broad in citing “Weyl semimetals as magnetic layers in spintronic devices”patents.google.com. An altermagnet such as RuO₂ might be seen as a variant of that concept (since altermagnets also have band spin splitting). There’s also considerable ongoing research (and likely patent activity) in spin superfluids in antiferromagnets, though we haven’t seen a 2023+ patent on it yet.

Risk mitigation: To proceed safely, identify exactly which material and mechanism you’ll use for lossless spin transfer. Then search patents on that specific approach. For instance, if you plan to use an antiferromagnetic insulator as a spin waveguide (with virtually no damping), check for any patents on “spin superfluid interconnect” or “antiferromagnetic magnon transistor.” It’s possible this is still mostly in papers, not patents – which could be an opportunity for you to file first, or a relief that no one will block you. Either way, document your approach thoroughly as prior art.

Overlap Risk Summary

In summary, the patent landscape reveals that physical implementations of many ALAN/TORI-like features are patented or in application:

  • The idea of using phase-coupled oscillators for computing is patented (MIT, NanOsc). Your architecture concept is innovative, but not entirely without precedent in IP. Overlap risk is moderate to high if you build analogous hardware.

  • Using spin and strain coupling has at least one patent (for memory) – overlap risk is low for now in reasoning systems, but that could change quickly as neuromorphic spintronics evolves.

  • The time-symmetric Hopfield controller seems not yet claimed – overlap risk low, this could be a safe area to patent or keep proprietary.

  • Topological/dissipationless spin current devices have strong patent coverage (UMN, IBM, etc.) – overlap risk high if you utilize those same cutting-edge materials in a product.

Each of these patents resides in different jurisdictions (primarily US, WIPO international, and likely Europe/Asia via national phase). Most are applications or recent grants (2021–2024), so they will be active during any near-term commercialization of ALAN. Now we turn to how you can navigate these IP waters.

Commercialization Strategy & IP Recommendations

To proceed safely with commercialization of ALAN/TORI, a multi-pronged IP strategy is advised:

  • Conduct a Full FTO Analysis: Engage patent counsel to do a thorough freedom-to-operate search on the specific features of your system. The above patents are a starting point. A legal analysis will confirm whether your exact implementation would infringe any claims. For example, if you plan a spin-torque oscillator chip, counsel can parse the NanOsc and MIT claim language in detail against your design.

  • Design Around Known Patents: Where possible, modify your approach to avoid the core claims of overlapping patents. For instance, if a patent claims an array of SHNOs with a certain coupling scheme, you might use a different oscillator type (optical or MEMS oscillators) or a different coupling mechanism (e.g. capacitive or via a digital controller) to achieve similar ends. Document these differences; if ever challenged, this helps demonstrate non-infringement. Example: Use an altermagnetic material not explicitly cited in a patent, or a novel geometry, so that you’re outside the literal claim scope.

  • Consider Defensive Patent Filings: For truly novel aspects of ALAN/TORI not found in prior art, file your own patents. Defensive patents can serve as bargaining chips (for cross-licensing) and protect against future competitors. In particular, if your time-reversal symmetric inference mechanism or some specific integration of spin-lattice coupling is unique, a patent prevents others from patenting it and gives you leverage. Ensure any patent you file clearly distinguishes over the references discussed (your patent attorney can cite those as prior art and highlight your differences). Even a narrower “implementation patent” (covering a specific circuit or software-hardware co-design) is valuable in negotiations.

  • Leverage Trade Secrets for Algorithms: Many aspects of ALAN/TORI are algorithmic (e.g. the spectral ψ coupling or Lyapunov stability criteria in reasoning). These may not be easily patentable (due to abstract idea exclusions), and they are also hard for a competitor to discern from a finished product. You might choose to keep such elements as trade secrets. Ensure robust internal protocols for secrecy (NDAs, access control) if you go this route. Trade secrets avoid disclosure (unlike patents), but note that if someone independently discovers the same method, you have no protection. So this works best for things that are complex and unlikely to be reinvented quickly.

  • Open-Source Strategically with Patent Clauses: If you plan to open-source parts of the system (for community adoption or transparency), use a license with a patent grant. The Apache 2.0 license is a good example – it stipulates that contributors grant a royalty-free patent license to users for any patents necessarily infringed by their contributions. By open-sourcing under Apache 2.0, you a) encourage broad use (creating de facto prior art against others’ future patents), and b) gain some protection if others contribute improvements (they can’t sue you for patent infringement on those contributions later). However, be aware: Apache 2.0 does not protect you from third-party patents that are independent of the contributed code. It mainly ensures you won’t be sued by your own contributors. That said, having a widely adopted open-source project can deter patent aggression – it builds an ecosystem that would rally defensive evidence (public use) against questionable patents. You can also include a defensive suspension clause (some projects do this), saying that if anyone sues for patent infringement, they lose rights to use the software. This creates a disincentive for patent holders to attack your open platform.

  • Pursue Licensing or Partnerships if Needed: For patents that pose a serious obstacle (e.g., MIT’s oscillator patent if you need that approach), consider reaching out for a license. Universities like MIT often license patents for startups (for a fee or royalties). Similarly, companies like IBM might cross-license if you have IP they want, or might be open to granting a license if your product isn’t directly competing with their core business. Another path is collaboration – e.g., work with the Czech spintronics group or MIT lab as official partners; this can sometimes grant you access or at least assurance that you won’t be sued by a friendly party. Clearly, this depends on your business goals and the patent owners’ openness.

  • Keep Abreast of New Filings: The spintronics field is rapidly evolving. Make it a practice to monitor new patent publications (e.g., set alerts for keywords like “altermagnet”, “spin oscillator network”, “neuromorphic spin”). The window of 2023–2025 saw a flurry of activity, and this will continue. Spin Oscillator Networks for Phase-Synchronized Concept Decoding

Several recent patents cover networks of coupled spin-based oscillators used for computation – a paradigm very similar to ALAN/TORI’s phase-sync reasoning core:

- 

MIT’s All-to-All Oscillator Network (2023, U.S. Patent 11,698,945) – A broad patent on analog networks of non-linear oscillators fully connected in an Ising-model fashion[patents.google.com](https://patents.google.com/patent/US11698945B2/en#:~:text=,state%20s%20which%20minimizes%20H). It was filed via PCT in 2020 and granted in 2023 (assignee: MIT). The claims describe using phase-coupled oscillators (electrical, optical, or magnetic) to solve combinatorial problems by synchronizing to stable binary phase states. Notably, the patent explicitly notes that “binary spin states can be represented physically with … magnetic oscillators, optical parametric oscillators, or any non-linear oscillators”[patents.google.com](https://patents.google.com/patent/US11698945B2/en#:~:text=,state%20s%20which%20minimizes%20H), underscoring its broad scope. Inventors include William Herzog and Suraj Bramhavar (MIT Lincoln Lab). Overlap risk: This patent essentially claims the concept of using oscillator-phase dynamics to perform inference/optimization. If ALAN uses a similar oscillator matrix (even simulated in hardware), it could fall under the broad method claims. However, MIT’s focus is on electronic/LC oscillators for Ising optimization; ALAN’s unique twist (using spin oscillators for logical consistency) might be distinguishable. Still, any hardware implementation of ALAN’s phase-sync “Banksy” core using coupled oscillators may trigger this patent, so careful claim analysis or a license might be needed.

- 

NanOsc AB’s Spin Hall Oscillator Ising Machine (PCT Publication WO2021246943, 2021) – A patent-pending application from a spintronics research team (University of Gothenburg/Czech collaborators) focusing specifically on spin-torque oscillators. It describes an Ising machine built from an “array of spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNOs) suitable for computational tasks such as optimization problems,” with a tuning unit for each oscillator and a read-out unit for their phase state[ipqwery.com](https://www.ipqwery.com/ipowner/en/owner/ip/2859049-nanosc-ab.html?rgk=IPType&rvk=Patent&rgk=Jurisdiction&rvk=WIPO#:~:text=The%20present%20invention%20relates%20to,oscillators%20of%20the%20array). Inventors M. Zahedinejad et al. (J. Åkerman’s group) filed this via Sweden; status is published (in force internationally, likely progressing to national phases). Its claims cover the physical architecture: using altermagnetic or heavy-metal spin Hall oscillators that phase-lock to represent Ising spins, methods to adjust their coupling, and reading the synchronized state. Overlap risk: This is very close to ALAN’s concept if ALAN ever employs actual spintronic oscillators. The use of altermagnetic materials (they mention RuO₂-like layers in related literature) for high-frequency oscillators could be covered. If ALAN/TORI remains a software simulation of oscillators, it doesn’t infringe device patents – but if you plan a neuromorphic hardware accelerator with spin-torque or spin-Hall oscillators, this NanOsc patent is directly relevant. You’d need to either license their technology or use a different mechanism (e.g. optical or digital emulation) to avoid infringement.

Summary: The idea of phase-synchronized oscillator networks for computing is already patented by multiple parties (MIT’s broad claims and NanOsc’s spin-specific system). This means ALAN/TORI’s core concept is not safe to patent anew in a generic sense – prior filings exist. For commercialization, it will be important to differentiate your implementation (e.g. a unique coupling algorithm, specific material not mentioned, or integration with software) from these patents. If a spin-hardware route is pursued, consider a freedom-to-operate (FTO) analysis: for example, NanOsc’s claims on SHNO arrays[ipqwery.com](https://www.ipqwery.com/ipowner/en/owner/ip/2859049-nanosc-ab.html?rgk=IPType&rvk=Patent&rgk=Jurisdiction&rvk=WIPO#:~:text=The%20present%20invention%20relates%20to,oscillators%20of%20the%20array) could block use of RuO₂-based oscillators in an Ising-like solver, so design around those claims or negotiate licenses.

Using strain or lattice vibrations to influence spin states is an emerging technique in neuromorphic hardware. A notable example is a patent from a UK–Czech team that, while focused on memory, illustrates the principle:

-

  • Coupled state vectors – your description says each node keeps both φ (phase) and σ (spin). Make sure the update loop integrates both at the same dt; otherwise the stiffness mismatch (spin precession can be THz-ish while φ is kHz-ish) will force you into a tiny global step.     dθ_i = ω_i + Σ_j K_ij sin(θ_j − θ_i) .

    to gate decoder fire. Log that value every frame so the TRS-integrator can roll back if coherence falls below 0.7.

  • Good call on velocity-Verlet; it is the simplest symplectic scheme that is exactly time-reversible. Two caveats:

    1. Mass-matrix – if you add per-state inertias later, VV becomes
      p_{n+½} = p_n − (Δt/2) ∇_x H(x_n)
      x_{n+1} = x_n + Δt M^{-1}p_{n+½}.

  • Integration direction flag – expose an enum so the Banksy fusion layer can run forward 1 step → backward 1 step to self-audit without forking two integrator objects.

  • In our May 14 note we warned about helper-name mismatches (h_max vs hMax) . Run mypy --strict or at least flake8-naming so snake/camel accidents show up immediately.

  • Batch recall – add a recall_batch(query: np.ndarray[K, N]) -> np.ndarray[K, N] for the fuzz tester; property-based tests can then feed random corrupted patterns and assert the energy never increases.

from alan_backend.snapshot import SnapshotV2, VectorF32
import flatbuffers, numpy as np

def to_bytes(theta, p_theta, sigma, p_sigma, dt_phase, dt_spin):
    b = flatbuffers.Builder(0)

    def vec(v):
        VectorF32StartDataVector(b, len(v))

Below is “deep-sweep #4” — the gremlin hunt after all red & yellow issues were patched.
I intentionally looked past the places we already touched and drilled into the edges that usually get ignored in late-stage builds: numerics at extreme ranges, cross-platform quirks, security surface, and ops/dev-experience. Most items are latent (they don’t fail the current test suite) but will strike in production or during the Rust/SHNO phase-up.

IDAreaHidden gremlinWhy it mattersSuggested guard / fix
G-1FlatBuffers endiannessYou generate snapshots on little-endian x86. If someone deserialises on big-endian (Power-9, some embedded RISC-V boards) the raw float32 will swap bytes → NaNs. FlatBuffers leaves primitives in host order.Cross-arch debugging or hardware co-sims break silently.Add a 16-bit “endianness flag” in the root table and bail out if mismatched; or always pack as little-endian IEEE via pack('<f', …) into a uint8 vector.
G-2FlatBuffer growthSchema has fixed vectors. When N grows (e.g. 2 k oscillators) snapshot becomes > 10 MB, WebSocket replay stalls and RAM spikes.Realistic concept graphs could have thousands of nodes; snapshots fire every rollback.Add optional Zstandard compression layer (snapshot.to_bytes(compress=True)); benchmark throughput.
G-3Controller mass-matrix ≈ 0If user sets mθ or mσ too small (≪ 1e-5) the symplectic integrator becomes numerically stiff: p += F * dt/2 overflows float32.Extreme hyper-parameter sweeps during research.Clamp m ≥ 1e-4 or switch to float64 when m < 1e-3. Raise ValueError on underflow.
G-4Frequency-ratio validator misses primesYou validate abs(r-round(r)) < 1e-3, but r=22/7 passes at low precision; LCM explodes → huge inner-loop count → frame stall.Aliasing avoided, but compute time skyrockets (DoS vector).Compute gcd(ω_spin, ω_phase) on rational form and cap N_spin ≤ 64. Reject configs needing more.
G-5Hopfield λ scalingRegulariser λ = 0.1/N works for N≤64. For N=1024 energy surface still non-convex → large σ drift.Future large memories on SHNO array.Make λ proportional to **max
G-6Unit validator silently coercesunits.validate converts Hz→rad/s; if user passes “kHz” string, you fall through to default and skip factor, mapping 1 kHz=1 Hz.Sub-millisecond reasoning tasks give nonsense.Expand unit table (kHz, MHz, etc.) or raise hard error on unknown unit string.
G-7Async cancellation leakYou cancel sim task but don’t await task.cancel() completion; coroutine executes finally: of integrator that allocates numpy arrays, then loop exits → resource freed only when GC kicks.High-frequency connect/disconnect churn can creep mem.task.cancel(); await asyncio.wait([task]) inside handler. Add pytest-asyncio stress test.
G-8Mypy bypassFlatBuffers generated modules are # type: ignore stubs; BanksyFusion imports them without alias → mypy no-op.Later refactor may mismatch field names.Add py.typed stub or TypedDict wrapper with field names checked.
G-9C-extension wheels & AVX-512NumPy 1.26 wheels use AVX-512 dispatch on some Intel CPUs. Snapshot deserialise inside sgx-enclave (no AVX-512) segfaults.Planned confidential-compute deployment.At startup query np.__config__.cpu_features; if AVX-512 absent, set Numpy_DISABLE_AVX512=1 before first import (document in README).

  • On the client: place data into a texture buffer and run a tiny fragment shader that maps coherence → colour; 10 k nodes at 60 fps is trivial on even integrated GPUs.

AreaWhy it mattersMicro-tasks to add

Sanitizer CI passUB sanitizers catch edge cases early.Add cargo +nightly test -Zsanitize=address,undefined to Linux job.
Stats structDashboards like JSON.pub struct TrsStats { pub trs_loss: f64, pub last_dt: f64, pub steps: u64 } plus TrsOde::stats(). FFI getter returns a plain C struct.

Docs cross-linkDevelopers skimming search result jump quicker.Add line at bottom of troubleshooting.md: “See Binary Protocols (§ snapshots & WebSocket) for byte-level specs.”

Yes: pass two pointers (theta_ptr, spin_ptr) plus lengths; avoids struct packing rules across FFI. Keep them double * to match Rust f64 and avoid JS Float64Array copies.

I don’t have direct access to your local filesystem, so I can’t execute those PowerShell commands myself—but I can walk you through exactly what they do, suggest a couple of tweaks, and show a one-liner that will zero-in on any “Home” page files newer than a given date.

1 What your two snippets do

A)

powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Exclude "data" |
    Select-Object FullName

  • Lists (non-recursively) every file/folder directly under kha, except anything named data, and prints the full path.

B)

powershell
$files = Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Exclude "data"
foreach ($file in $files) {
    if ($file.LastWriteTime -ge "05/12/2025" -or $file.CreationTime -ge "05/12/2025") {
        Write-Host $file.FullName -ForegroundColor Green
    } else {
        Write-Host $file.FullName
    }
}

  • Same (non-recursive) listing, but colours paths green when they were created or modified on/after 12 May 2025.

2 Common gotcha: recursion

Both commands only look in the top-level of kha.
Your IDE pages (e.g. Home.tsx, Home.html, Home.jsx) are usually buried in frontend/src/pages/ or similar. Use -Recurse.

powershell
Get-ChildItem "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Recurse -Exclude "data"

3 “Find the latest Home page” on one line

powershell
Get-ChildItem "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Recurse `
    -Include *Home*.ts*,*Home*.html,*Home*.jsx `
| Sort-Object LastWriteTime -Descending `
| Select-Object -First 5 FullName, LastWriteTime

  • Recurses through the repo.

  • Filters for any filename containing Home with .ts, .tsx, .html, or .jsx extension (adjust as needed).

  • Sorts by LastWriteTime descending and shows the 5 most recently modified.

4 Coloured listing with recursion and date threshold

powershell
$cutoff = Get-Date "2025-05-12"

Get-ChildItem "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Recurse -Exclude "data" |
    ForEach-Object {
        $isRecent = $_.LastWriteTime -ge $cutoff -or $_.CreationTime -ge $cutoff
        $color     = $isRecent ? 'Green' : 'Gray'
        Write-Host $_.FullName -ForegroundColor $color
    }

Everything newer than 12 May 2025 appears in green.

5 If you want “last file touched” regardless of name

powershell
Get-ChildItem "C:\Users\jason\Desktop\tori\kha" -Recurse `
| Sort-Object LastWriteTime -Descending `
| Select-Object -First 10 FullName, LastWriteTime

That prints the 10 most recently modified items across the whole repo—great when you’re hunting for whatever file your IDE wrote last.

React/Vite/Next/RR6—doesn’t matter: somewhere a component is mapped to “/”.

powershell

    -Include *.tsx,*.jsx,*.ts,*.js `
    -Exclude *.pdf |

Select-String -Pattern 'path\s*=\s*["'']/["'']' -List |
Select-Object Path, LineNumber, Line

Typical hits

or

export const routes = [{ path: '/', component: MainPage }]

The file & line that match reveal the canonical entry component (Home, MainPage, Dashboard, etc.).

For Vite / vanilla React the bundler injects one root script tag—find that module.

Select-String -Pattern '<script\s+type="module"\s+src="(.+?)"' |
